title: Infant Scalp Score
description: Assesses risk of traumatic brain injury in infants with asymptomatic head injury and isolated scalp hematoma. The Infant Scalp Score (ISS) is a validated clinical tool specifically designed for infants ≤12 months old who present with isolated scalp hematoma after head trauma but are otherwise asymptomatic. The score stratifies risk for clinically important traumatic brain injury (ciTBI) or TBI on computed tomography (CT) to help guide clinical decision-making. This tool is particularly valuable in the pediatric emergency setting where infants are difficult to assess clinically and are most sensitive to ionizing radiation effects. The score considers patient age, hematoma size, and location to calculate risk, helping clinicians determine which infants require neuroimaging versus those who can be safely observed.

parameters.name: patient_age_months
parameters.description: Patient age in months. Younger infants have higher risk for traumatic brain injury due to anatomical and physiological factors

parameters.name: hematoma_size
parameters.description: Size and consistency of scalp hematoma. Larger hematomas indicate greater force of impact and increased risk of underlying brain injury

parameters.name: hematoma_location
parameters.description: Anatomical location of scalp hematoma. Non-frontal locations, particularly temporal/parietal, carry higher risk for underlying TBI

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of traumatic brain injury. Clinical observation may be appropriate. Consider shared decision-making with family regarding CT imaging based on clinical judgment and family concerns.
High risk of traumatic brain injury. Strong consideration for cranial CT imaging to evaluate for clinically important traumatic brain injury or TBI.

references: Schutzman SA, Nigrovic LE, Mannix R, et al. The Infant Scalp Score: A Validated Tool to Stratify Risk of Traumatic Brain Injury in Infants With Isolated Scalp Hematoma. Acad Emerg Med. 2021;28(1):16-24. doi: 10.1111/acem.14087.

Kuppermann N, Holmes JF, Dayan PS, et al. Identification of children at very low risk of clinically-important brain injuries after head trauma: a prospective cohort study. Lancet. 2009;374(9696):1160-1170. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61558-0.
Greenberg JK, Jeffe DB, Carpenter CR, et al. North American Survey of the Management of Minor Head Injury in Children. J Trauma Acute Care Surg. 2018;84(4):613-619. doi: 10.1097/TA.0000000000001808.
formula: Score = Age points (0-3) + Hematoma size points (0-3) + Hematoma location points (0-2)
notes: Validated for infants ≤12 months old with isolated scalp hematoma after head trauma
Only for use in asymptomatic infants (no loss of consciousness, seizures, mental status changes)
NOT for use in suspected non-accidental trauma cases
Score ≥4 indicates high risk and strong consideration for CT imaging
Score <4 indicates low risk where clinical observation may be appropriate
Some studies suggest ≥5 as cutoff for clinically important TBI
Helps avoid unnecessary radiation exposure in low-risk infants
Temporal/parietal hematomas carry highest risk (2 points)
Younger age groups have progressively higher point values
Large boggy hematomas indicate significant force and carry highest size points
Tool assists in shared decision-making with families
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and PECARN guidelines
Particularly valuable when clinical assessment is challenging in infants
Validated against clinically important TBI and TBI on CT imaging
